head.title: Ode III. To Tweed.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 155-158; reprinted as “Ode to the Tweed” in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 19, 1796), 4.

lg.l: Far, Tweeda,22 Running through the Borders region of Scotland, the River Tweed forms the boundary between Scotland and England. from thy banks I stray,
Where Glotta’s33 Roman name for the Isle of Arran, in the Firth of Clyde, visible from the Ayrshire coast. swelling surges roar,
No more the verdant fields survey,
That stretch along thy winding shore.
Yet pow’rful fancy’s magic spell,
Oft wafts me to thy silvan bow’rs:
Those lov’d restarts, that pleas’d so well,
Among the fragrant blooming flow’rs.
Where, free from ev’ry anxious care,
That sours our more advanced age,
Gay as the birds, that wing the air,
I gently pass’d youth’s golden stage.
No wish, that from ambition springs,
E’er stopp’d the progress of my mirth,
Nor love, that ev’ry sorrow brings,
E’er gave a sigh or murmur birth.

No cruel Delia44 Alternative name for Artemis or Diana. Citing Tibullus, Maurice Scêve (1510-64) and Samuel Daniel (1562-1619), Alastair Fowler argues that Delia was often used to denote purity. See Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 44. there appear’d,
No nymph my tender fancy fir’d,
No rival’s fatal form I fear’d,
With equal love and hate inspir’d.
Oft, at the early dawn of day,
Along thy verdant banks I stray’d;
Or, scorch’d by Sol’s meridian ray,
Enjoy’d the coolness of the shade.
Or, list’ned to the lulling lay,
Of streams attuned to the gale,
Or warbling minstrels, of the spray,
Or piping shepherds, in the dale.
But O! what joy, when winding slow,
Yon mountain’s airy top to gain;
To gaze upon the scene below,
The stream, the woodland, and the plain.
Where, from the mazy river’s side,
The hills above the vallies rise;
And, proud aspiring, seem to hide
Their peaks among surrounding skies.
The forests wave their verdant heads,
There fertile cultur’d fields extend;
Rich palaces o’erlook the meads,
And tow’rs, and shining spires ascend.

A Gothic ruin,55 [GT's note: Melrose Abbey.] Described at length in Francis Grose’s The Antiquities of Scotland (1797), pp. 122-133, St. Mary’s Abbey, located in Roxburghshire, has been in existence since 664; from 1136 up to the Reformation, the abbey served as the house of the Cistercian order; in 1610 a portion of the abbey was converted into a parish church but fell into disuse after 1810. in the wind,
There hangs in fragments sore decay’d,
My pencil oft its tow’rs design’d,
Its niches, and its spires pourtray’d.
O happy days, of peace and rest,
Days never, never to return,
Your dear remembrance, in my breast
Remains, and still your loss I mourn.
